title: General Knowledge Quiz XV (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair across art, history, astronomy, cities/landmarks, and SI units. No sports content.

items.q: Which early 20th‑century movement emphasized geometric forms and multiple viewpoints?
items.a: Cubism - pioneered by Picasso and Braque

items.q: Which movement explored the unconscious and dream imagery in the 1920s–30s?
items.a: Surrealism - associated with Dalí, Magritte, and Breton

items.q: Which style used dramatic light and shadow contrasts known as chiaroscuro?
items.a: Baroque - exemplified by Caravaggio and Rembrandt

items.q: What is the technique of painting with pigment mixed into hot wax?
items.a: Encaustic - used in ancient Fayum portraits

items.q: Which movement celebrated modern life and technology with speed and dynamism?
items.a: Futurism - Italian avant‑garde of the 1910s

items.q: What is the method of applying paint in tiny dots of pure color?
items.a: Pointillism (Divisionism) - practiced by Seurat and Signac

items.q: Which decorative style of the late 19th century featured flowing lines and organic motifs?
items.a: Art Nouveau - exemplified by Mucha and Horta

items.q: Which 1960s movement used imagery from advertising and mass media?
items.a: Pop Art - led by Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein

items.q: What term describes mural painting on fresh wet plaster?
items.a: Fresco - pigments bond as the plaster cures

items.q: Which Japanese woodblock print genre flourished in the Edo period?
items.a: Ukiyo‑e - ‘pictures of the floating world’ by artists like Hokusai

items.q: Which conflict in North America culminated with the Siege of Yorktown (1781)?
items.a: The American Revolutionary War - decisive Franco‑American victory at Yorktown

items.q: Which 1789 event marked the beginning of the French Revolution?
items.a: The Storming of the Bastille - July 14, 1789

items.q: Which 1848 publication by Marx and Engels outlined a critique of capitalism?
items.a: The Communist Manifesto - influential political pamphlet

items.q: Which 1917 declaration expressed British support for a “national home for the Jewish people” in Palestine?
items.a: The Balfour Declaration - letter to Lord Rothschild, November 2, 1917

items.q: Which 1918 armistice ended fighting on the Western Front of World War I?
items.a: Armistice of Compiègne - signed November 11, 1918

items.q: Which 1947 partition plan proposed separate Jewish and Arab states in Mandatory Palestine?
items.a: UN General Assembly Resolution 181 - Partition Plan of 1947

items.q: Which 1954 agreement ended French colonial rule in Indochina?
items.a: Geneva Accords - temporarily divided Vietnam at the 17th parallel

items.q: Which 1962 agreement resolved the Cuban Missile Crisis?
items.a: U.S.–Soviet understanding - withdrawal of missiles and secret Jupiter removal from Turkey

items.q: Which 1978 accords led to the Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty?
items.a: Camp David Accords - brokered by U.S. President Jimmy Carter

items.q: Which 1993 agreements established Palestinian self‑governance in parts of the West Bank and Gaza?
items.a: Oslo Accords - Declaration of Principles signed on the White House lawn

items.q: Which planet is known for its prominent Great Red Spot?
items.a: Jupiter - long‑lived anticyclonic storm larger than Earth

items.q: Which Martian volcano is the largest in the solar system?
items.a: Olympus Mons - shield volcano about 22 km high

items.q: Which moon of Jupiter is believed to harbor a subsurface ocean beneath an icy crust?
items.a: Europa - potential astrobiological interest

items.q: Which ringed planet has a hexagon‑shaped jet stream at its north pole?
items.a: Saturn - hexagon discovered by Voyager, observed by Cassini

items.q: Which dwarf planet in the asteroid belt was visited by NASA’s Dawn mission?
items.a: Ceres - first dwarf planet discovered (1801)

items.q: Which moon of Saturn has geysers erupting from its south polar region?
items.a: Enceladus - jets of water ice discovered by Cassini

items.q: Which planet has the highest mean surface temperature due to a runaway greenhouse effect?
items.a: Venus - dense CO₂ atmosphere traps heat

items.q: Which two planets lack natural moons?
items.a: Mercury and Venus - no confirmed satellites

items.q: Which moon is the largest in the solar system?
items.a: Ganymede - larger than Mercury

items.q: Which planet has a day about 24 hours long, similar to Earth’s?
items.a: Mars - rotation period ~24 hours 37 minutes

items.q: Which city is home to the Kremlin and Red Square?
items.a: Moscow - capital of Russia

items.q: Which city’s opera house is famed for its sail‑like design by Jørn Utzon?
items.a: Sydney - the Sydney Opera House, opened in 1973

items.q: Which Italian city is known for its Leaning Tower?
items.a: Pisa - freestanding bell tower of the cathedral

items.q: Which city features the Christ the Redeemer statue atop Corcovado?
items.a: Rio de Janeiro - 1931 Art Deco statue

items.q: Which city’s Golden Gate Bridge spans the entrance to a Pacific bay?
items.a: San Francisco - suspension bridge completed in 1937

items.q: Which Egyptian city houses the Great Pyramid complex at Giza?
items.a: Giza - part of Greater Cairo metropolitan area

items.q: Which Indian city contains the Gateway of India monument?
items.a: Mumbai - arch built to commemorate the 1911 royal visit

items.q: Which British city has the Roman baths and Georgian crescents giving it UNESCO status?
items.a: Bath - famed for thermal springs and Palladian architecture

items.q: Which Chinese city hosts the Forbidden City palace complex?
items.a: Beijing - imperial seat from the Ming to the Qing dynasty

items.q: Which Turkish city straddles two continents?
items.a: Istanbul - spans Europe and Asia across the Bosporus

items.q: What is the SI base unit of amount of substance?
items.a: Mole (mol) - defined via Avogadro constant 6.02214076×10^23

items.q: What SI unit measures electric charge?
items.a: Coulomb (C) - equals one ampere‑second

items.q: What is the SI base unit of luminous intensity?
items.a: Candela (cd) - defined via monochromatic radiation at 540 THz

items.q: Which SI prefix denotes one billion (10^9)?
items.a: Giga (G) - examples: gigabyte (GB)

items.q: What is the SI derived unit for pressure?
items.a: Pascal (Pa) - one newton per square meter

items.q: What is the SI base unit for temperature?
items.a: Kelvin (K) - defined via the Boltzmann constant

items.q: Which SI prefix denotes one trillionth (10^−12)?
items.a: Pico (p) - examples: picometer (pm)

items.q: What is the derived SI unit for frequency?
items.a: Hertz (Hz) - one cycle per second

items.q: Which SI prefix denotes one millionth (10^−6)?
items.a: Micro (μ) - examples: microliter (μL)

items.q: What is the SI base unit for length?
items.a: Meter (m) - defined via the speed of light in vacuum
